content.description: This route climbs a short face to a right facing corner.  About midway up a bolt augments the not so great protection.
content.location: Obvious far right crack on Alpentine Wall

climbs.name: Potlicker
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Dana Adler, Cyndie Bransford, Derek Reineg

content.description:
Scramble up broken rock to where the rock steepens and then slab past two closely spaced bolts leading to a ledge. Downclimb off left down easy terrain.

Useful as an alternative approach to

Illegal Campfire

or one of the other routes nearby. One star out of five.
content.location:
Left side of the Alpentine Wall on a slabby apron below

Illegal Campfire

.

content.description: Begin climbing on the coarse face, below the overhang, on the left side of the alcove/left facing corner. Climb up and left using side pulls on the sculpted hueco feature. Continue up and left on featured rock with numerous pod-like crevices. Once established to the left of the overhang move right on a wild, but awkward stemming maneuver to pass the bulge. Climb over a pair of large boulders. Move up and right above a deep void to the base of a right slanting, flaring crack. Pull into the crack on flared pockets and the flakey face on the right. Continue up the crack to a featured face to a ledge with a wide hand crack for the belay.
content.protection: Several small cams (C3) to 3." Fiddly protection in small slots and flaring cracks.
content.location: Begin 40 ft. left of "Alpentine" below a left facing corner in a recess or alcove. Just left of the right facing corner, between Potlicker and Alpentine.

climbs.name: Kalishnakov Culture
climbs.fa: Dave Bengston, Scott Cole, and Bob Gaines, 1990.

content.description: This climb has had all the hangers removed from the bolts.  The studs remain, however.
content.protection: 4 bolts (3 w/o hangers) so TR only now

content.description: On the brown wall up and left of "Alpentine" is an obvious left-leaning crack. Climb up 3rd class to the base, then climb the crack.

This is a fun route, and an obvious line. This is on the left (West) end of the south face of Campfire crag. The line is visible from quite some distance away, popping up through a roof from a well defines cave-like arch and climbing the leaning crack above. It is the second crack from the right of the group of climbs on this feature.

The bulging crux is interesting, but littered with good holds. Climb up easy rock, place a few aliens or TCU's back in cracks just before the bulge, (long slings) then clip a bolt & pop up and over into the slightly right-leaning crack. The climbing eases up after a few moves.
content.protection: A single bolt near the crux move suppliments the standard trad rack protection. Below the bolt, small TCU's and aliens are the best option.

climbs.name: Full Day Runner
climbs.fa: 1st known ascent: Amanda Vickery, EmIly Fuller Nov. 2015; 1st known free ascent: William and Dawn Brunner 2/18

content.description: Start up the face, then step left across to the overhanging rock. Climb the pantina to a large shelf with a hole that goes all the way to the ground. Step across this hole to climb the vertical crack above (the central of the three cracks).  Getting into this crack is the crux.  Climbing the right leaning crack for a few feet then stemming back to the vertical crack seems easiest.  Top out on a wide sandy shelf.
content.protection: Unless you place gear far to the right, the first placement doesn't come for 12-15 feet.  Also, I used a 2" cam and 3" cam to protect the crux, smaller gear for the rest of the climb.
content.location: This route starts just to the right of the right facing overhang between the start of Mother's Little Helper and Alpentine. Top is the right side of the same sandy shelf as Potlicker. (See topo photo of the route.)Â  Descent is a 3rd class scramble to the left (connects with descent of Potlicker).

content.description: To the left of "Genuine Cowhide", climb buckets, a pillar, and the left facing corner above.
